Review title: 10 for Quality of Production, -9 For making a Hero out of a Charlatan
Review_body: Smoking is bad for you. Duh. But when you know just a little bit of science you see right through this "whistle-blower's" claims. Tobacco companies added a chemical extracted from plants to give their product a more pleasant smell. They added green-leaf-volatiles; the chemical that gives fresh cut grass its pleasant smell. Jeffrey Wigand called it "rat poison." Warfarin is a rat poison in huge quantities and can be made from green leaf volatiles, it is also a life-saving drug that prevents strokes and heart-attacks. So the "whistle-blower" lied to make himself appear to be a hero. Tobacco companies called him a liar and were telling the truth, but since they are tobacco companies we have to believe every lie told about them. This movie fictionalized his exaggerations into a full-blown melodramatic hero-flick.

I was ready to go to sleep in the first scenes. Foreign scenes, etc... Hubby fell asleep. Two hours later I was stunned by a wonderful movie. I spent hours the next morning Googling "Wigand" and "Big Tobacco" and "CBS" etc etc etc. It was a movie about tough men in tough grinding, no-holds situations. An insight into the workings of not only corporate America, but also, how we as Americans receive our doses of fed "media. And products. I was in tears at the end. For everyone. But not because it was schlock...there is no time for schlock in this movie, but because it was so damn frustrating. Good stuff. Great movie.

This is truly an amazing film. I would consider this probably Michael Mann's best movie (besides "Heat"). In this movie, Michael Mann show's us how great a director he is. And the screenplay is just great in my opinion. I do have to say one thing though, I have read other comments about this movie, and Pacino barely receives recognition for his performance. The focus is mostly on Russel Crowe. Now don't get me wrong, Crowe did do a fine job portraying Dr. Jeffery Wigand, but Pacino was amazing as Lowell Bergman, the producer of CBS's 60 minuets. Now, this movie is based on a true story, and Pacino and Crowe delivered grand performances as these real life men. It's a shame that Pacino didn't receive an Oscar nomination for his performance, because he deserved it. Overall, this film is excellent, and I recommend it to anyone who enjoys real drama's and especially if you are a Pacino fan.

This could have been a really terrific movie.  The acting was amazing and the story was well written.  Unfortunately Michael Mann's direction was awful.  I'm not quite sure what happened, since he did such a good job with "Heat."  In "The Insider" he constantly uses awkward focusing techniques and hand-held cameras- it's like watching "The Blair Witch Project" but worse because you're trying to follow a complex plot, but people's heads keep shifting in and out of focus, and the camera keeps zooming around in blurry close-ups, that I got dizzy every scene.  The movie was too long at almost 3 hours, it could have easily had 30 minutes or so cut. The problem is I really liked this movie.  I was looking forward to it, Mann's awkward direction and often out-of-place music cues detracted a lot from this film- I can only honestly give it ** out of **** stars.  Its a real shame, this could have been an incredible movie.  Pacino, Crowe, and especially Christopher Plummer were fantastic.  Really unfortunate.

I thought the movie made very good drama out of a story that might of otherwise been rather dull (I am not a follower of the smoking industry scandal). Fine performances all around, but particularly by Russell Crowe. I would only dispute some of the directional choices with respect to what I would say was dramatic effect over charaterization.For example, the extreme closeups and the soundtrack (much as I enjoy that kind of music) often made me wonder when someone was about to get shot; impending danger, yes, impending extreme violence, a slight overstatement, no? Additionally, I think a few corners had been cut in the characterizations of some of the important supporting roles such as Liane Wigand, and Mike Wallace. I felt the former's exit from the marriage seemed premature relative to immediate context of the narrative; similarly, Wallace's decision to side with CBS Corporate seemed to come out of left field. I believe in both cases the story could have foreshadowed a little better the capacity for the characters to eventually make the decisions that they did (the restaurant meeting scene wasn't enough to me). Instead, we saw extensive footage given to the opening Iranian sequences, the Unibomber sequences, though plotwise their relation to rest of the story was rather inconsequential.Moreover, I felt that the film towards the end dropped the development of who I thought was the protagonist, Wigand, to concentrate solely on Lowell Bergman's heroism. I think I would have like to see more of Wigand as 'survivor'.These points downgraded the film's quality for me, though on the whole, very good!

Best movie of '99. Probably, of the last 5 years, and very possibly, of the decade. Brilliant direction. Rich, powerful performances. Intelligent, literate and realistic screenplay. Beautiful cinematography. Go see this film. Then go see it again!

Review title: If you want to give up smoking...
Review_body: Wow! I didn't smoke for a couple of days after watching this movie. Amazing! If you're really serious about quitting; watch this movie every time you're tempted...Besides that: Very nice acting by Al Pacino and Russell Crowe. Tension rises throughout the movie.

Review title: i must agree - good not great
Review_body: The insider, although wonderful at some parts, in my opinion, is not all it's cracked up to be. Russell Crowe and Al Pacino do give stellar performances, but I found this movie to be extremely slow! To give an example, the scene at the driving range is one of the longest and most unneeded scenes in film history. The entire scene could have been cut in half, at least. As a movie fan, I am all into long shots, but this was ridiculous!!! The story was indeed intriguing, but the way it was presented was nothing that needed to take 2 and a half hours of my time. I believe the actors did well with  what they were presented, however, and I cannot state this enough, it was just way too slow and long!!!!

Review title: The most engrossing, clever film of 1999
Review_body: The Insider is based on the true story of two men who fight to get public information out to the public. Lowell Bergman (Pacino) is a producer of 60 Minutes. Jeff Wigand (Crowe) is an ex-executive at Brown and Williamson (America's 3rd largest tobacco company). When Bergman approaches Wigand to be a consultant on a fire safety study on cigarrettes Brown and Williamson blackmail him into furthering his confidentiality agreement. Bergman can tell that Wigand has something to say but can't. So he sets up Wigand to testify in a court of public opinion on behalf of the state of Mississipi. He does, and he also does a CBS interview on 60 Minutes with Mike Wallace (Plummer). The information is simple. That the tobacco industry has been lying to the people about nicotine. That it is not only addictive but they also manipulate it to increase its addictiveness. But big tobacco are trying to do all they can to shut Wigand up. They use restraining orders, they treating CBS with a lawsuit and they start a smear campaign against Wigand. All these things separate Wigand from his family and Bergman from the rest of CBS. This was a fantastic movie. It deserved all 7 of the Oscars it was nominated for. Michael Mann's direction is impeccable as he shows what the people are thinking and the emotions they are feeling. The film is long but very engrossing. The film switches half-way through from Wigand giving the information to Bergman fighting to air the information. Al Pacino shows that he is one of the best actors in Hollywood with an Oscar worthy performance. But the star of the show was Russell Crowe as Jeff Wigand. His performance is perfect as a man torn between what is right and what is best for his family and he stops short of showing Wigand to be a persecuted hero, but as a man whose whole life is threatened by what he knows. Out of 10 i will give this film 9.5
This film looks so dated and cliched now, probably was cool and clever back in 99. The film was very long, lots of filler and no killer.

Boring plot, characters with no depth and no empathy, no suspense or mystery, I turned it off before it finished and I never do that.  A total waste of time.  I like Pacino, but never saw him worse, and Crowe, who is mediocre at his best, was even worse than that!

This is one of the few videos I returned without watching the whole. It was impossible to empathize or sympathize with any of the characters.  And dull! Looking at others' votes, maybe I'm weird, but that's my take.  Don't waste your time.
I love Russell Crowe he is insanely talented and Al Pacino plays a great character. Reveals the terrifying reality we live in...

Review title: To smoke or not so smoke
Review_body: CBS shackled by tortuous interference is forced to shelve an interview that reveals it all about the addictive and harmful ingredients added to cigarettes. A very controversial Michael Mann movie that shows CBS and Brown and Williamson in bad light. An interesting episode right before the release of this movie was when a Miami judge ordered jurors in a multi-billion dollar tobacco lawsuit not to see 'The Insider' saying the fictionalized version could prejudice the panel. In India too, we need to take steps to keep the judge and the jury away from the media interpreted stories and public voices, especially in cases like the Jessica Lal and the Nithari killings.

It's a good film. But isn't anyone annoyed by Pacino that his acting is always the same since "Heat" ???! Different role, same guy. Too bad. Great acting, don't get me wrong. But in a strange way with a Steven Seagal frequency. Seagal plays different characters, but he plays em like Steven, and not like the role requires. See where I'm getting at? Pacino since '95 is always acting like " Watch out, I'm Al Pacino; I'll show you how it's supposed to be done!". Loved the film for the story by the way:-) Just a humble side-opinion from The Netherlands! P.S. After seeing the film I kept on smoking though. But it did make me think: Before cigarette's was "Coke" a- Cola addictive?

The Insider is a film which easily could have easily been boring and forgettable, yet the tight script, superb cinematography and outstanding performances of both Russell Crowe and Al Pacino make it a compelling viewing experience. Michael Mann did an outstanding job of maintaining tension throughout the film, perhaps best exemplified in the scenes with lots of yelling, such as Wigand calling up Bergman after his confidence had been betrayed, the courtroom scene and the multiple times Bergman argued with his superiors.On the negative side, I found the accent of Wigand's wife (Diane Venora) very off-putting and felt that maybe 5-10 minutes of the film could have been shaved off.

Simply one of the best movies of the past 5-10 years. I left the theater thinking "that is what a movie can be!"Well acted, top to bottom, with masterful direction and writing by Mann. Most inspiring is Mann's willingness to use SILENCE, a concept lost to almost every director in the post-sound era. Music is added when necessary (as is dialogue, of course) but Mann lets the gaps do much of the work, to great effect.Pacino, brilliant as always, using a bit of his Ricky Roma salesman character, tempered with the heart of an idealist. Academy Award should go to Crowe, however, who turns in a career-making performance. Rest of cast strong in support.

I can understand why the validity of the truth behind this film might be questioned.  However, you have to realize that you have to see this movie for what it is:  A powerful story about strength, hope and how an individual can overcome REALISTIC, overwhelming odds.  Ironically enough, another film like this one was also overlooked by the academy, whose characters used hope and strength to survive more life-threatening situations: "The Shawshank Redemption".From the movie's excellent direction (a superior ability to make a thriller without action and still maintain the quick pace), wonderful screenplay,haunting musical score and especially the fantastic acting) will be a film to be remembered for a long time.The acting is incredible.  Plummer's performance as Mike Wallace is frightenly real.  Pacino finally gave up his screaming method-acting he picked up in "Scent of a Woman" and gave a subtle, energetic portrayal that is his best in years.But the actor who gives the movie its heart is Crowe's Wigand.  His is a performance that shows realistic struggles of what this man is going through and what he loses.  And when he does get his emotional battle scars, he maintains his silent composure, but reveals his pain through his eyes. His is the best portrayal of "an ordinary man facing an overwhelming circumstance" and should be an example of how to face our problems like a fighter, not a victim.I was extremely disappointed that he did not win for best actor.  Although I am a Kevin Spacey fan,  Crowe's was the most multi-layered, and the transformation was more thorough.  Unfortunately,  for the last 3 years, the academy has been blatantly showing that it's not the best performance that wins, but who is the most popular.  3 years ago, it was Jack Nicholson and Helen Hunt who won for "As Good As it Gets", instead of Judi Dench for "Mrs. Brown" and Peter Fonda for "Ulee's Gold" (or Robert Duvall for "Apostle").  Then, 2 years ago: Gwyneth Paltrow for "Shakespeare in Love" and Roberto Benigni for "Life is Beautiful" instead of Cate Blanchette for "Elizabeth" and Nick Nolte for "Affliction" or Ian McKellan for "Gods and Monsters".  Now, Kevin Spacey came out of the blue for "American Beauty", based on this popularity.  The only redeeming factor was Swank winning for "Boys Don't Cry".Again, I'm a fan of Spacey's, but Crowe, as well as many others in this film, were robbed of the recognition they deserved. Perhaps the inspiration that is generated from the film to the viewer is good enough.

From scene one, this film delivers a long slow burn as the tale of power and corruption unfolds. There is little action, but the film is steeped in an atmosphere of tension and high drama. The direction by Michael Mann is masterful, an object lesson in how to frame shots and let silence, as well as words - and music - work for the story. Al Pacino is once more the great actor of early films such as 'Scarecrow', instead of the theatrical performer of recent films.  Russell Crowe shows his solid 'ordinary guy'character as more tortured through losing his family than any of the macho scenes he portrayed in 'Gladiator.'  A superb film.

All I can say that the first three hours of this movie was okay, but the final twelve kinda got to me.. Oh.. the movie was only 2 hours and 50 minutes.. well it fooled me. Anyway, if you're absolutely dying to see this movie, go see it, then kill yourself. It really is that bad. The only reason I saw it is because I was "guilt tripped" into it by a kid I know that just wanted to keep a girl "happy." Nuff said. After seeing that, I'm ready to see "The House on Haunted Hill" about 40 more times to make up for the 2 and a half hours that wasted my life. Yeah, "The House on Haunted Hill" was pretty damn bad too... but somehow better than "The Insider"

Review title: Great acting but the movie was long!
Review_body: This movie was truly a masterpiece when it comes to acting. Having said that let me also say that the movie was long and it's span was felt by the crowd.There were many scenes that could have been easily avoided and edited out of the final version. The movie is also extremely "quiet". There are many moments where people stare at each other for an average of one and a half minute without really "connecting" with the crowd.Again the acting by EVERYONE was superb. And Michael Mann's touch was evident throughout the movie. When the "Insider" was standing at the beach pondering the result of his actions it was pretty much a modern version of Sonny Crockett at the Miami beach before he had to arrest his girlfriend.I think that the movie-goers that are going for action will be disapointed. However those of you that are in for a good suspence film and would like to see how reality sometimes is better than fiction this film is truly one of the best out there.

I walked into an advanced screening of this film thinking it should be okay at best.  Mann's last film "Heat" had all of this hype surrounding the casting of Deniro and Pacino.  And a lot of people were left feeling let down by "Heat" (including myself),  but this film the "Insider" draws you in like some type of cinematic whirlpool.  I will not spoil the movie but merely state how this film affected me.Russell Crowe gives a great layered performance as the main character.  In the way he conveys the pressure he is being put through by the tobacco company, 60 minutes, his family and all sorts of other influences is almost painful but stunning to watch.  At times I wanted to yell at the screen and say "will you just leave the guy alone". Truly a man against the world feeling.  Pacino is very understated but powerful when the script calls for it.  I thought he was very well cast as the producer for 60 minutes.Another great aspect of this film is the way it lays bear the inside workings of the television and print media.  I thought stock brokers werebrutal.  Truly interesting to watch and to witness how a news story comes together.Well all in all a great story with well acted characters through out this film.  If you feel like being interested and educated by a film.  Well the "Insider" is most definitely for you.

I went to see this movie in the theater and I really enjoyed it.Michael Mann is excellent at creating films that are long as well as entertaining.  I have not seen a movie that long that is that good since "English Patient".Al Pacino as Lowell Bergman was very good.  He has the right kind of acting qualities to play this role.Russel Crowe as Jeffery Wigland was not the greatest performance but I thought he did a good job.The supporting cast was good as well.  Christopher Plummer was good as Mike Wallace.  Debbie Mazar was good as Debbie DeLuca.  Diane Venora was good as Wigland's wife and Gina Gershon had a small role yet an excellent one as Helen Caperelli.This is definitely one to see in the theater!

In a nutshell, I thought this movie was terrific.  I have been waiting for it to come out, which is rare for me to await any release date.  Michael Mann, Al Pacino and Russell Crowe all deserve a great deal of credit for wonderful direction and superb acting.It was a thriller that relied on legal obligations, the corporate bottom line, a journalist's obstinance and another man's beliefs to drive its impact.  I will likely see this movie again.

Just came back from watching The Insider, and I must say that I thought it was absolutely excellent! The acting was incredible by both Pacino and Crowe, and the rest of the cast - I definitely recommend people see it. It has all the elements a great film should have! I give it two thumbs up! Brilliant film:-) Elle

The Insider shows a remarkable improvement on commercial american Movies both in its contents and from. this one is departing from the predictable patterns that most of the American film industry is tied to. the expression is also very creative, visually and also with a very unusual music highlighting technique. i wish american producers would do more of this, trying to shape the taste of the general public instead of shaping themselves around existing demands.

Because the subject of "The Insider" appealed to me, and because I like Michael Mann's work (Heat, Last of the Mohicans, Manhunter), I decided to go and see it, even though I felt slightly tired and I knew the running time was 2½ hours. Well, the start of the movie (let's say, the first half an hour)was quite good. And of course, Russell Crowe (who I loved in the Australian film 'Proof') and Al Pacino are good actors. But the film went on forever, everything was so elaborate it just became tedious and overdone; it just didn't manage to reach the point that the viewer became really 'captured' and involved in what was happening on-screen. The occasional witty remarks of good old Al Capone (as I like to call him as an hommage for all his gangsta' rolls) were a relief, but after some time even this became a bit of a bore. He tried too hard to be a clown, it seemed, and it didn't really fit in the basically serious story. It wasn't just as tedious as another Capone film, 'City Hall', which also dealt with corruption on high political levels, but it came quite close. 5 out of 10, I'm sorry, Mr. Mann. Incredible that the IMDB users voted an average of 8.4...But: "de gustibus non est disputandum".

Review title: A perfectly directed emotional thriller with a great cast and incredible performances.
Review_body: The Insider is one of the most incredible movies I have ever seen. The movie is totally devoid of sex, violence, gunshots, car chases, huge explosions, overblown special effects, cheap gags, false sincerity, clichés and cute animals. And yet it is utterly absorbing, gripping and powerful, a story of how two (fairly) ordinary guys face an overwhelming situation. The chemistry between Al Pachino and Russell Crowe is electrifying. Micheal Mann has directed the best movie of his career with superb camera work, soundtrack and compelling performances. Don't believe what you hear - it isn't too long, in fact it wasn't long enough. It had my total concentration from start to finish and it left me emotionally drained.Summary: A perfectly directed emotional thriller with a great cast and incredible performances.

Review title: It tells you the truth! Impressive performance by Al Pacino
Review_body: It's extremely realistic in its history, and reflects the society we're living in and the media world. Al Pacino is fantastic, his role is simply heroic. Still, the movie is a bit too long and some details in the characters are not convincing: can you believe a top manager of a tobacco multinational still has to finish paying his car and is so worried about losing his job??? Come on...

Review title: George Clooney couldn't save this one..
Review_body: Starts out slow and just gets slower.  We fell asleep several times trying to get through this.  On the bright side, they may have discovered a cure for insomnia!  The whole thing is disjointed.  Lots of characters, very little development of any of them beyond the 2 main characters.  The wife is so insignificant that you don't even care when she leaves him.

Review title: Boring, cheesy, and this inexpressive Australian actor
Review_body: I'm surprised everyone seems so highly captivated by this slowish and rather pointless movie.As usual since he's played Shakespeare, Al Pacino doesn't play his character - he just plays Pacino, ie he has his shakespearian tirade, like in Any Given Sunday, The Devil's Advocate, etc.And there's Russel Crowe - the man with one expression (or no expression at all ?). Is it boredom, fatigue or disgust ? Anyway, it's the same mask as in Gladiator !Then there's the pace of the film - or rather it's lack. I must say I've had to watch this movie (on DVD) on several moments, pausing after each 30 mn not to fall asleep.If you want to see what kind of masterpiece action-packed movie with DEPTH Michael Mann can realize, then (re)watch Heat !I rate this film 2/5.

Review title: Riviting movie, left you on the edge of your seat.
Review_body: The Insider is the story of Jeffery Wigand (again Oscar-worthy Russell Crowe), a former tobacco company scientist that begins to rebel against his former employer.  With the help of 60 Minutes producer played by Al Pacino. Wigand tells the story of what the tobacco companies do not want you to know.  He then realizes that maybe everything he is doing isn't worth all he has lost, (i.e. his family, his safety, his job).  This film was a real controversial masterpiece of modern times.  It was nominated for 7 Academy Awards, and though I agree with giving Best Picture, Actor, and Director to American Beauty, this film should have won something, possably Best Screenplay.

Review title: An inside look at 2 moguls, 60 Minutes and the Tobacco Industry
Review_body: When you put two people like Al Pacino and Russell Crowe, you know you have a good thing.This movie, although a bit on the lengthy side at 2 and a half hours, keeps you pretty much involved the entire way.  Al Pacino plays great journalist looking for the big story, but gets personal when Russell Crowe loses his job as a researcher for a big tobacco firm, and starts to come loose at the edges because of some damaging information he is aware of.The movie provides some very original plot twists, and kept it surprisingly real.  They probably could have cut about 30 mins of footage, but after seeing Mike Wallace freak out...I can understand the length.  I definately recommend, but get comfy.

Review title: If only all films were this cinematic, this engaging.
Review_body: ***SPOILERS***   ***SPOILERS*** Having taken the crime thriller just about as far as it could go with his last film, Heat, writer/director Michael Mann has shifted his attention to staging this gripping and elaborate drama-documentary. Based on a true-life magazine article, The Insider follows the contrasting fortunes of Jeffery Wigand and Lowell Bergman, two men driven by different incentives, yet both compelled into achieving the same result: to reveal to the American public the shocking truth that will result in the biggest public reform issue the nation has ever seen. Having been unfairly fired, Wigand, a former research scientist at tobacco giants Brown & Williamson, is prepared to go on national television and reveal the facts behind the company's part in 'impact boosting', a chemical process designed to artificially increase the addictiveness of nicotine. Bergman, a producer at CBS' '60 Minutes', one of the country's most popular prime-time current affairs shows, feels it is his programme's moral duty to air what Wigand has to say, claiming it is the public's right to know. However, after agreeing to go ahead with the interview, Wigand comes up against several moral and legal dilemmas. By spilling the secrets he knows, he will be breaking a still-binding confidentiality agreement he signed with Brown & Williamson. They in turn have made it clear that by going public, Wigand will be placing the lives of his family in jeopardy, while at the same time risking a lengthy prison sentence for himself. Making constant use of stark close-ups and jittery, anxious camerawork, The Insider succeeds on several levels. As a drama, Mann's film is both engaging and compelling, with his deliberate, urgent directing invariably drawing the viewer into the heart of the scenes, almost placing them at the centre of the arguments in the boardrooms and courtrooms on screen. Mann has always been a visual stylist, but here he restrains from many of his familiar trademarks, opting instead for many long, hand-held, often amateur-looking takes. But if we look beyond any technical concerns, his chosen style of shooting only adds to the claustrophobic nature of the characters' situations, giving the entire film a documentary-like feel. He allows his camera, and therefore the viewer, to intrude upon, rather than merely record, scenes that often seemed improvised as a result. The performances from the leads only add to the impression that we are witnessing a real drama rather than a movie. As Wigand, the Oscar-nominated Russell Crowe is outstanding, giving his character a nervous vulnerability, while carefully avoiding the cliches of the helpless victim. He also manages to characterise the growing frustration and anger Wigand feels at being trapped and threatened into silence by forces more powerful than he'll ever be. The audience can only sympathise with his plight. While, as the determined and ethical Bergman, Al Pacino is his usual forthright self, wading through a legal and moral minefield to achieve what he believes is right, while berating anyone who stands in the way of him keeping his promise of giving Wigand a public platform from which he could blow his whistle. A film laden with both cinematic and dramatic substance, The Insider proves to be a very rewarding experience for those prepared to endure its two-and-a-half hours running time. Along with co-writer Eric Roth, Michael Mann has crafted a memorable, intense, and great-looking movie, one which is made all the more satisfying by his focusing upon the characters rather than the increasingly complex legal wranglings. Instead of allowing his film to drown under the weight of corporate red tape and boardroom-level corruption, he is sure never to stray too far away from the human centre of his drama, always careful to remind the audience that the characters on screen are as real and as flawed as they

This is an excellent film not only for the fine portrayal of a man faced with exposing a corporate conspiracy, but also the pressures on the media that militate against airing such issues. Watching this film brings a new appreciation for reports and documentaries that challenge the status quo. I was particularly reminded of the little-known but powerful documentary "Taken for a Ride" (1996), not only because of the similarities in broad plotlines (corporations doing whatever it takes to maintain or enhance their "market"), but also because of the recognition given to the complex relationships between stakeholders at the corporate AND (more importantly, as the film emphasises) the individual level. Crowe and Pacino are exceptional here. This is not a "fireworks" action film but it maintains a very palpable tension. See it (and keep an eye out for "Taken" - if it hasn't already been buried sopmewhere!).

Review title: You will be able to get some Courage from this movie!!
Review_body: This movie has an air of tension from beginning to end. I was excited about the battle of two men up against the tobacco industry. And I'm surprised that this movie is based on a TRUE STORY.Russell Crowe played "Jeffrey Wigand." He's a good scientist who works for a tobacco company. He's an ordinary man who loves his family. One day he learns secrets inside of his company. Therefore he is discharged unfairly. The company uses the duty of confidentiality as a shield. They threaten him. He is caught in a moral dilemma between releasing the truth and protecting the secrets. His conflict is painful.Jeffrey meets Lowell Bergman(Al Pacino)who is the producer of a news program for CBS. Jeffrey decides to release the truth,being encouraged by Lowell. Lowell and Jeffrey continue fighting with the tobacco industry. They use neither violence nor a gun,Lowell believes in the power of journalism.The two men's courage and beliefs,and the image of them fighting against the wall of power are so strong that you will be greatly impressed. When you finish watching this movie,you will be able to get some courage from them.

Well, I thought Al Pacino did some of his best work here. Noting that Russell Crowe got a nomination (Oscar), I felt that even stronger was the role played by Al. Russell did his best work here and later they thinly veiled an Oscar as a, so to speak, "make up call"...I mean come on! Oscar for gladiator and not Insider! Reminds me of Rod Steiger missing Oscar for the Pawnbroker (Lee Marvin's Cat Ballou")and getting the make up for "In the Heat of the Night". The comment concerning Al's control within the character is so accurate...noting that he contained his energy until it was important. When he gets the Hotel employee to knock on Crowe's door and tell him to pick up his phone and then Al says to tell him to "just pick up the f...king phone", Russell crosses the room and picks up the phone and the two have at it....so visceral! Oscars for the two...and outstanding roles for everybody else from the Wallace character to the plaintiff attorney in the courtroom in Miss. One of my all time ten best!!! Jim G

Review title: One of the best political/corporate thrillers
Review_body: A brilliant, incisive, academic, fast-paced political/industrial thrillers. Michael Mann manages to show a cold, threatening world in which the courage of an opinion, the pursue of truth can change a man's life for the worst, and the lives of those who interact with him.The plot is solid and takes you back to state-of-the-art thrillers such as John Frankenheimer's "The Manchurian Candidate" or Alan Pakula's "All the President's Men".Added to that, the impeccable performances of Russell Crowe and Al Pacino (actually, perfect cast all along). Mann takes out the best of actors and lifts them to the excellence of acting. The photography is as beautifully somber and mysterious as in "Heat" and music score takes the movie to even higher levels of drama and suspense.

Review title: One of the best movies on corporate corruption('s) I've seen.
Review_body: Yes, the message is very clear. Nicotine IS addicting. But it is the way that the tobacco corporation handles such issues that I also take note of. Russell Crowe was excellent, even in his mannerism's of acting like the Sr. Corp. VP, a powerful position. Al Pacino was excellent as the guiding force behind trying to help Jeffry Wygand get his message to the masses. Even the wife's character was played to a tee. I took it as "They used to love each other, in some other life", but the prestige and power involved corrupted them both to a point where they grew apart. The father truly loved his little girls, the mother was more worried about "what the neighbors will think" of their sudden misfortune of losing a job, and having to move to a lesser neighborhood. (family values? What family values! It's about how we look, not the love). hehe. Anyway, I really enjoyed the movie. As a compliment to this one ... the BOOK "Runaway Jury" would be an excellent look into Big Tobacco's theme. And way of doing business.Michael Mann is a genius. This movie has a way of drawing the viewer right into the minds of each and every main character. In particular, the scene of Jeff in the hotel room, and it panning off to the walls giving way to the picture of his 2 daughters playing, looking at him from a great distance. Despair. Anguish. Anger. And even Defeat. Coupled with the music Michael Mann used, ... I was on the edge of my seat. I was right there, feeling the exact same emotions as Jeff W. was. WOW! Excellent directing, producing. Nothing short of a Michael Mann movie.

Review title: A Great Movie, Very Underrated, Due To Poor Marketing
Review_body: Russell Crowe at his best as a Kentucky tobacco executive in Eric Roth and Michael Mann's masterpiece, "The Insider," is one of the most underrated American films ever. Not only is it important historically for its political implications - not about tobacco, but about conflicts of commercial interest that control freedom of speech along the airwaves in the U.S.- it is a great story and it is true. Disney had no idea how to market "The Insider" and essentially sold it as tobacco movie and it is so much more. Pacino gives a grand A plus performance as a Long Island Jewish producer and halfway through the movie I forgot he was Al Pacino. Even better Christopher Plummer masterfully captures the full essence of Mike Wallace. Gina Gershon could turn lust from a stone as always. Michael Mann seems to always pull strong performances from his actors, and Eric Roth who brilliantly adapted "Forrest Gump" did the same here with Mann. Though long, "The Insider" is never boring and a movie all Americans should see twice to make sure they fully comprehend regardless of how you feel about the tobacco debate.

It's rare to find a movie of this stature. Brilliant performances by Pacino and Crowe, especially the former. The pace is intense, the direction brilliant! Not a flaw in this one. Go watch it! Your every minute will be well spent.

I saw this film on television on April 11, 2003. Right after the US-invasion in Bagdad. Right after the US-ambassador in Brussels told the press that he didn't like how Belgian media commented on the US-operation in Iraq. The Insider is about pressure on the press by big international concerns (in this case the tobacco industry). Since the Bush-administration in the USA took over, the interests of industry and government overlap. How free can the press be when this happens? Not all journalists are as brave as Lowell Bergman. Some Americans should read about the evil propaganda methods of Goebels (remember?). And Michael Mann has still a lot of shooting to do to make clear that the freedom of the press is essential in democracy, as important as opposition in Congress, as important as the voice and the clearvoyance of Mr Michael Mann himself. R-E-S-P-E-C-T T-H-I-S M-A-N.

The movie is filled with great actors to be sure.  But even the best acting can not save an otherwise dull story.  The movie is dull for two reasons. Everyone is now aware that smoking is not healthy, so that aspect of the movie now seems uneventful.  The movie is constrained from having flashing action scenes, because real life is not that way and this story is suppose to be remotely close to life of a real insider.  The most troubling part of the film is its length.  It needs to be cut by at lease 45 minutes to be more bearable.

From seeing the trailer and hearing that the movie was a true story about a corporate whistleblower in the tobacco industry, I didn't think that this movie would be terribly exciting.  I did know, however, that this was Michael Mann's next project after "Heat"(1995), a movie near and dear to my heart, and that was what brought me to the theater.It turns out that I was thoroughly captivated by this story from minute 1 to minute 157. Told by any other director this may have been a real bore but the combination of Michael Mann, Al Pacino, Russell Crowe, Christopher Plummer, Dante Spinotti (camera), and the musicians make this movie incredible. Usually when I watch a movie that uses extensive cutting between two protagonists, one is more boring than the other and I can't wait to get back to the good one.  In this movie, the scenes with Russell Crowe are just as good as the ones with Pacino.I couldn't find a hole in the acting amongst anyone including Gina Gershon who I thought might screw it up.  Russell Crowe plays a perfect defensive, upper forties(he's really only 35), corporate and family man.  Al Pacino plays a perfect upper forties man (he's really 59) at the top of his profession.  I can imagine that it would've been pretty easy and tempting to vilify Mike Wallace but you won't find that here. Christopher Plummer portrays an intelligent Wallace who made me feel as if each of his decisions were rightly motivated by what he says is his main concern, getting old."The Insider" is shot very similarly to "Heat" in that there are many, many, telephoto and macro shots.  Michael Mann must have the fastest lens available to be able to shoot telephoto in the dark with decent depth of field.  This closeness has a way of making a city look like a place made up of just a few people, who you get to know very, very well.I think Michael Mann has outdone "Heat" here and even though it probably won't get any Oscars, it should.

Forget the poetic liberties taken with the actual events (e.g., Dr. Wigand's daughter has spina bifida, not asthma), the petty putdowns and complaints about casting choices, makeup, pace of the movie, etc., and side plots such as section on the Unabomber stakeout towards the end. This film is a riveting tale of corruption in corporate America, of valuing money and personal advantage above traditional, basic fundamental human values such as respecting human life and telling the truth. Two courageous but imperfect men, and their allies, prevail in the face of an army of greedy, dishonest, egoistic, cynical people surrounding them. As such, this film does a masterful job in telling this story, in a powerful fashion that no documentary (well, perhaps if Ken Burns produced it, and Stephen Ambrose was still around to be interviewed, not having succumbed to smoking induced lung cancer) could have conveyed. It's a heroic, well-crafted morality tale, and well deserves its comparison to "All the President's Men." In fact, I think cinematically it is much better.

After Heat, I was a little worried that Mann wouldn't be able to present the same level of character, intensity and drama on what would seem to be a "boring" subject matter. How wrong was I.Russell Crowe and Al Pacino both give outstanding performances. Crowe is one of the most talented "new" actors around. See L.A. Confidential for proof.Mann's use of intense lighting, close-ups and wide landscape shots to establish atmosphere are more refined than in Heat. While most directors either ignore the environment and how it relates to the story or characters, or use it as eye candy, Mann understands the importance of atmosphere. Music, photography, lighting, all can say more in a single scene than most directors can get across in a whole movie.I have to respectfully disagree with Gooch-4 about the lack of focus of the film. The story is about ordinary people in extraordinary circumstances. Wigand is the ordinary person thrust into the center of the maelstrom. We need to see Bergman's fight and the corporate happenings to understand the full extent of Wigand's struggle. As to the "why," it seems fairly obvious that Wigand simply set out to do the right thing.

I honestly would have given this only a 9 due to a teeny few overblown scenes, but I am so galled that the movie isn't ranked higher that I gave it a 10.  =)Make no mistake, this is a mental thriller.  Nobody gets sliced, diced, there is no nudity, and remarkably little swearing.  I guess considering modern society's taste for instant gratification and our increasingly short attention span, I should be surprised it didn't score even lower.But this is a thinking person's movie, and a damn good one at that.  Don't expect big explosions and sudden slaughters... you won't get it.  Even without knowing that this was all based on a true story, I enjoyed every minute of the movie... and I think anyone who watches it with an open, unhurried mind (sprinkled with a dose of imagination) can't help but be enthralled.One comment on how poorly the movie did during the *laughs* Oscars and the *groans* Box Office:  as time goes on, both these institutions become more and more bland, with the oh-so-corporatized aim of pleasing the great masses by sticking to the least common denominator.  But maybe the movie wasn't a commercial success just because The Insider is just too left-of-center. Maybe some really subtle pressure from some really large powers-that-be urged that it really shouldn't do so well...  hmmm, what do you think?

I'm a film junkie, and that means that not only have I seen every film that is out right now, but I have been choosy in recommending films to my friends. This movie, THE INSIDER, has been infused with so much care in its direction, it is a much rarer commodity than many would think. Yes, it was long. Yes, Michael Mann likes long.But what does that matter, for a film that can put one in touch in the most basic levels with a character that you don't really know much about for those 2 and some odd hours?Coupled with an unusually  good performance (for production company movies) put forth by Russell Crowe as Jeffrey Wygand, this film, with its dramatization, worts and all, brings forth more truth about America than any film on the block in the past few years.

Review title: The (poorly made) Truth is Stranger than Fiction
Review_body: An intersting story only because it is real. This movie was overly dramatic with horror film music and to close to the real characters to make you believe.  It was longer than it needed to be with too much time spent trying to be a horror flick. This could have been portrayed dramatic without the cheesey antics.

Review title: Should have waited till more in the mood for a slower-paced movie
Review_body: Great movie, but I should have seen it when I was in a more contemplative state of mind.  Russell Crowe's performance is fascinating--Al Pacino always grabs my attention--and I found myself quite curious about what has happened to Jeffrey Wigand since the events depicted in the film.

Topic could sound boring at first glance but I was on the edge of my seat the entire time.  Portrayal of Wgand's wife was very sad, but I have also known real life stories of women that could not or would not stand by their man (sad but true).  Very realistic and credible since I have worked for a large Corporation and the power and money issues are amazing. Crowe deserves an ACADEMY AWARD - Casting decision would have been a hard one for Wigand since the director and writer wanted to show a sensitive side to the character - a great choice since result showed a  strong/ethical and yet sensitive character.....Absolutely a great film.............

I thought this was an extremely well made movie.  Michael Mann is at the top of his form.  Russell Crowe has turned in an excellent portrayl of Jeffrey Wigand.  Christopher Plummer was so believable as Mike Wallace there were times I forgot it wasn't really him.  Al Pacino is always a joy to watch. He makes acting seem so simple and flawless.  The pace was slow but my interest was held throughout, and this type of story benefits from the slower pace.  The only discordant part for me was the music, but after a while I really didn't notice.  I recommend this movie highly for inteligent adult fare.

Truly a great film.  The best work Michael Mann has ever done and the finest work Al Pacino has done in a long time.  Russell Crowe deserves his Best Actor nod for a restrained and understated performance.  Also impeccable casting for all of the smaller roles .The film has a consisent visual style and tells the story patiently without being indulgent.  Great editing, great sound and a compelling script based on a true story.

Review title: A very interesting and well paced drama
Review_body: I was looking forward to this latest release by the man Michael Mann, as his past efforts include "Heat" & "Last of the Mohicans", both of which I own on DVD.The Insider just shows how a movie can be made to grip you without the need for action sequences. All actors in the film excel themselves as portraying the characters essential to the story in particular the mighty Pacino as the investigative journalist and Crowe as the insider, looking to uplift the guilt of working in America's tobacco industry.If you are looking for a movie in which you have to think with the movie as it progresses through its twists and turns, then this is one hell of a show. If however you are expecting action sequences then forget it, as the only bit of action is Crowe rolling down the lawn in front of his house!!!Essential viewing if you are a Pacino fan, and not to be missed as a film on the whole.

Review title: Although liberties were taken, the overall truth is overwhelming.
Review_body: As evidenced in the movie, the magnitude of the power of the cigarette industry and corporate tv is shocking.  One can only heave a sigh of relief that there are still some, as portrayed in this movie,  that still consider their moral integrity more important than illegal pressures from such groups. The acting was outstanding, although my family had a problem at times figuring out where we were due to the hop-scotching without warning technique used in trying to get the story out.

By far and away Michael Mann's best film, with outstanding performances by Crowe, Pacino and Plummer. A true story of tobacco industry exec turned whistle blower to the 60 mins TV program, but for me the real message of this film is that anybody can be a hero as long as we stick to what we believe in.

Review title: A real life thriller about an American hero!
Review_body: "The Insider" is an exceptionally well acted and well produced film.  It faithfully tells the true story of Jeffrey S. Wigand, a former top executive with Brown and Williamson tobacco company, and the man who "blew the whistle" on his former employer with his now famous interview with Mike Wallace on the CBS news show "60 Minutes."This film is interspersed with superb performances by Russell Crowe (as Wigand), Al Pacino (as CBS news producer Lowell Bergman) and Christopher Plummer (as Wallace.)  The screenplay crackles with tension in this real-life drama; the film has a dark, taut and suspenseful mood which kept me completely engrossed from start to finish, and reminded me of another true-to-life film with similar themes of "whistleblowing" and journalistic integrity: "All the President's Men.""The Insider" is a movie I will view and savor...over and over again!!

Review title: For once, something good out of Hollywood
Review_body: I can't believe it - for once, a movie with things like ... hmm, let me see if I remember those things ... oh yea - Plot! and ah ... Acting, yea Acting! and ... storyline, yea! and ... Characters, yea, Characters!Wow, a real movie.  The worst part about variable reinforcement schedules is that the payoff takes so long, the good part is that once something good happens, it seem really good compared to all the other garbage out there.Not recommended for people who need sex and violence to feel alive and satisfied.  Highly recommended for people who feel starved for what Hollywood so rarely gives us - good work.

Review title: Great Film, would have been a classic if half an hour shorter
Review_body: The film is very good. It's been said before but its closest rival is all the president's men. The reason that president's is a classic is that it is more tightly edited. Half an hour of screen time isn't needed. If i were Mann I'd re-edit, minus at least 25 minutes, release it as a director's cut (against the general trend of such things to be longer) and it would be an almost flawless piece

Review title: Garbage, A True Waste Of Film
Review_body: I am an avid movie watcher, and generally a movie lover.  But in this case I am going the other way.  The Insider was a great story, a decent plot, but was horribly filmed.  If they would have cut off about 45 minutes it would have made a huge difference, but I found it just plain boring.

Review title: Tension from the start, attention to the end
Review_body: We thoroughly enjoyed this movie and we were watching it on the small screen.  Pacino was the professional we expected, while Crowe showed a new dimension to his range.  This was no Gladiator.   Rent this, book this - you wont be disappointed

First of all, this movie is not for people that enjoy shallow, flat, or poorly written scripts. The Insider is an informative true story that shows us how Dr. Jeffrey Wigand (Russell Crowe) chose to fight and reveal the lies of the tobacco company Brown & Williamson. We see how it cost him his family, his reputation, and forever changed his life. Al Pacino does an amazing job of portraying the 60 minutes producer Lowell Bergman who helped Wigand along his journey of emptiness, heartache, and frustration in order to show the American people the truth. Russell Crow gives the performance of his career, and Al Pacino again shows America what real acting is all about. With the magnificent script from Eric Roth & Michael Mann and the beautiful score by Lisa Gerard & Pieter Bourke, we receive one of the most powerful and gripping movies of 1999.

Review title: A must-see for all smokers in the world!
Review_body: A must-see for all smokers (and non-smokers as well) in the world! Great movie, perfectly played by the actors. They had me nailed to my chair for the full length of the film. The rotten thing is though, that it's a true story....

Review title: One of the few movies which makes it matter and makes it count.
Review_body: I finally saw the movie last night in one stretch. Have always missed the beginning or the end or the middle when it comes on TV. And I was engrossed and as drawn in this time round, even though I knew what was going to happen.Without giving too much about the plot, Jeffery Wigand (Russell Crowe), decides to blow the whistle on his employees, a big tobacco company. And he chooses to do so on America's premiere Television News show, 60 Minutes, which is produced by Lowell Bergmann.The script by Eli Roth and Michael Mann is tight and has some intelligent writing. This was possibly Mann's triumph in using hand held camera work, which has in the last few years adapted by people like Winterbottom, Greengrass and Liman.But the film's aces are the actors...and all of them. Led by the paranoid and even guilt ridden Russell Crow who must make the choice between family and his conscience. Crowe's body language, his nervous twitches steal the show the much seasoned Al Pacino, who delivers a usual strong performance. Christopher Plummer too has some great moments of acting.Overall a great film. A must watch for all, especially in today's climate, where news is not we are made to believe it is, and as Al Pacino says, 'Heros are scarce!'

Michael Mann proves again to be one of the top directors in the business. Despite its length, the film never lacks pace or tension. Al Pacino is in full form without going over the top and Russell Crowe delivers a stand out performance and shows he's got better from the promise of Romper Stomper. Not for pop corn audiences, top drama.

Film review: The insider An encounter between two honest men who dedicate their lives seeking "truth" in their jobs - this is the plot of The Insider, a film directed by Michael Mann. In one part of this story the chief protagonist is a journalist who believes that news may change the way people perceive the world. This man is Lowell Bergman and he produces the TV show 60 minutes. The second main character is Jeffrey Wingand, a chemist who worked as executive and researcher for big corporations, including one of the biggest tobacco companies. Just after being fired from his last job, Wingand starts thinking of the crooked strategies used by the tobacco industry to addict its consumers. Wingard and Bergman are both constrained by corporate rules yet they must fight against them to maintain their own principles. Maybe they simply know too much and can't hide certain company secrets anymore. In reality, Jeffrey Wingand did indeed denounce certain claims made by the US tobacco industry. He stated that the tobacco CEO's knew exactly what substances were inside each cigarette. Wingard's testimony was the first step toward changing the relationship between the US government and the tobacco industry. It was also a big media event planned and detailed by an unknown producer of one of the biggest US TV shows. Besides this true story, The Insider focuses on the personal drama in which the characters are driven by moral conflict. Both Wingard and Bergman expose their choices in obtaining their victory. They were ordinary people under extraordinary pressure. On the other hand, they also gave up vital everyday values, such as security and stability. It is not by chance that Wingard's wife asks him for a divorce. For his part, Bergman quits after working more than a decade for 60 minutes. Their personalities and values clash with corporate regulations and their employers react in a hostile manner. Wingard and his family are pursued and investigated. Bergman is not allowed to show his program as he wished. All the professional and ethical values to which they dedicate their lives suddenly disappear. From the corporation's point of view, business and law are more important. In other words, the professional status and security they enjoy appears to be a company possession.

Review title: Here you see real people struggling for what they believe is right
Review_body: I've just  seen this movie and I found it absolutely great. Basically what I like about the movie is that you see several people who are all trying to live according to their own basic values, and those values tend to clash every now and then. It starts with the character Wigand who, having worked in the health-care industry now accepts a job with a tobacco company because of the high salary they pay. He then finds out that no matter the salary, he can not live with the consequences of his work. Upon protesting to the nature of his work, he is fired. At one point, his wife leaves him, with the motivation: "I really want to support you, but I can not take this kind of life" In other words, she wants to support her husband, but finds that she is not able to muster the strength needed to full fill her wish. When Al Pacino hears that his interview is not to be broadcasted because of the risk to CBS, one of his colleagues who has a financial stake in CBS says "Are you accusing me of being influenced by the money". Where upon Pacino answers with sarcasm "No I'm not accusing you, you are a volunteer, you work for free just like me. Of course you are influenced by the money!" Time and time again you see these scenes where you can understand the motivation of all the characters involved and you can also understand that every one of them is trying to do the good thing, even though they vehemently disagree about what "the good thing" would be. Whereas I can understand that this movie leaves you in a depressed state of mind because it shows you how very far the power of large cooperations actually goes, it can also give you a boost. Most people here act out of their will to do good. At the end, the movie increased my faith in humanity.

This movie is genuine art - unlike 99% of what is out there. This is the best movie I have seen. Casting excellent. Script excellent. Cinematography excellent. Soundtrack excellent. Every one of the characters is robust and phenomenal. The main characters in most movies are not as developed as background characters are in this film. It took me a while to even believe that Russell Crowe was the same person as the lead in Gladiator. While I feel that Pacino plays more or less the same way no matter his character, he really suits this movie. Even supporting characters have memorable scenes and dialogue in this movie, my favorite being the courtroom deposition of Wiegand (Crowe). This movie provides intensity on so many levels. There is action (not shootouts or car chases...), suspense, heroism, depression, hope - you name it. There is abundant complexity in the plot, especially in regard to Wiegand being pushed to the edge of sanity. Lisa Gerrard (vocals) is perfect as usual for adding drama and feeling. The camera work in my opinion - while a different beast - is on par with Saving Private Ryan, Gladiator, and other famed movies. If you prefer movies that don't follow the conventional, cliché plot, this is one you must see.

Review title: best movie I've seen in a while
Review_body: I am an avid movie viewer, and this is one of the best movies I have seen in a while. What's surprising is that I am not even a huge fan of the director, or Crowe...and Pacino is playing a character he's played in previous films, so his good acting did not influence my opinion. I just think the general acting from all involved is superb(notably the 1 court room scene), there is a lot of tension throughout the movie, and the story is very interesting and poignant. Comparing this to other similar movies: JFK by oliver stone lacks the tension that the insider has. Heat by mann, while enjoyable, is not as tight. OK That is all.

I worked on The Sunday Times, London, Insight team for 4 years. The film mirrors, for me, the thrills and the angst in discovering accurate and truthful facts that Governments (including democratically elected ones) and powerful 'organisations'do their level best to connive to keep secret. The Insight Team's exposure of the KGB's poison pellet 'umbrella' killer's methods from being revealed, and the inside story of the uses of the UK's SAS London Iranian Embassy siege were some of those I personally experienced.Jeffrey Wigland deserves to be canonized for his bravery and service to mankind. Al Pacino and Russell Crowe portray exactly the experiences some of us (investigative) journalists (all journalism is investigative, surely) go through. Exhilarating in helping right a wrong, and ensuring people know the truth.Once people know the truth (the whole truth) they are able to make proper and responsible decisions. Truth exposes falsehood and cant which are scourges.

Before coming to "The Insider," I had no idea of Michael Mann. After watching it, I have been literally hunting for his movies around and watching them one by one. This is by far one of the BEST movies Hollywood can or will ever produce. The subject is delicate and extremely well handled; movies on whistle blowers are not uncommon, but showing the corporate corruption and the cover-ups that upper echelons of the society engage in needs some mastery over detail and know-how. The real insider for me is Michael Mann. I would be belittling Al Pacio and Crowe if I attempt to say anything about their performances in the movie; words cannot describe it. I watched the movie eight times in a space of three months and bought the DVD to watch it couple more times. It gives me the feeling that this is what any movie should be about--reality, hard core reality exposing the corruption inherent in the systems we trust in. Be it CBS or Brown and Williamson, their corporate honchos must have squirmed in their seats while watching this movie (if they had the ticker to do so, that is). The courtroom scene needs special mention: "Wipe that smirk off your face"--these six words actually set my heart pounding, making me feel as if he was shouting at me. It was so naturally done that I could almost feel I was there in the courtroom. Just watch it; no one will EVER regret to be an insider to the brilliance of THE INSIDER.

In this busy modern life we often face corruption,injustice,inequality more or less . But few of us fight against it and perform moral and civic duty .
Because Keeping our mouth shut and maintaning status quo is much easier and safe . But a brave few finds the courage stand against this kinds of
things,rising above their limitations and self-interset . This people make us question our conscience and duty . Such a story is of this film .
Talented Jeffrey Wigand works as a researcher in Brown & Williamson . When it decides to apply a secret formula to their products,which will
increase nicotin absorption in human body, Jeffrey challenges this decision and gets fired for doing so . Losing his job creates problem in his
family life . On other hand Lowell Bergman,who is the producer of famed tv show 60 Minutes is investigating tobacco companies gets in touch with
Jeffrey . Who is reluctant to say anything about his company's wrongdoing because his contract with the company .
When his company finds out his meeting with the journalist,they threatens him and his family . A simple man like him becomes the target of a billion dollar
company . His wife divorces him,making things worse . Jeffrey loses everything for fighting for truth . Having been cornered he decides to go public
against all odds . But broadcasting of the show is halted under the pressure of big tobacco . Will the truth come out ? Will Jeffrey's sacrifice go in vain ?
To know you have to watch it .
Nothing new could be said about the performance of two brilliant actors like Russell Crowe and Al Pacino . And accomplished director like Michael Mann
has done his job perfectly .

I'm not one for art. Too much nonsense is called art because people are afraid to challenge the value of something if it's called art. I'm also not one for most Hollywood movies. They are so cookie cutter. I truly wonder what compels people to go see movies that are obviously going to be just like tons of other movies they've already seen. The Insider is special. It is art. It is compelling. When I explain it to people...I can't. It's too good to explain, like Michelangelo's Pieta or Roger Federer's forehand. This movie is based on reality. The camera work is stunning. The limited special effects are sublime. The music is exceptional. The actors are perfect. The suspense sucks you in and doesn't let go. The combination of them all makes this the best movie I've ever seen.

Russell Crowe turns inn what is quite possibly his best performance to date as a man coming to terms with what he feels is the right thing to do and what he feels is maybe the easiest thing to do.The supporting cast does an excellent job as well with everyone bringing a great deal of drama to a story that is already riddled with it. The cinematography inn this film is absolutely exceptional with the camera most of the time being hand held right up there in the actors faces. Crowe earned his first Oscar nomination for his role in this film along side Oscar veteran Al Pacino. The key ingredient though in all of this talent being shown is the man behind it all. I am speaking of course about one the best and brightest filmmakers working today, Michael Mann.

Review title: A good story but far too long
Review_body: This is a good story but far too long.. drawn-out scenes, unnecessary repetition of clips, etc. They could have cut at least half an hour and made it a much better film
